characters: A SERIES OF STILL IMAGES MOVE US FORWARD IN TIME
O'HEARNE IS MOBBED BY A THRONG OF REPORTERS ON THE STREET
3/4 OF A BOTTLE OF SCOTCH LATER
IDENTIFIED ON SCREEN, A PATHOLOGIST RESPONDS TO REPORTERS
"LEO FASOLI, FAMED ITALIAN PAINTER, DIES AT 66."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tumbler of Scotch. A half empty bottle of Macallan's. A burning Montecristo cigar in an ashtray. A hand picks up a telephone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'd like to speak with my wife.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (groggy) ; ; Barney...? It's three in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Put my wife on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: She's not your wife and I'm not waking her.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Then just ask her what she wants me to do with these nude photos I have of her. Come to think of it, you might actually want them if only to see what Miriam looked like in her prime. Click. Dial tone. Barney hangs up, puffs on his cigar. Feeling good. Photos of him and Miriam strewn over the table. None of them nud

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bottle of Macallan's now empty. The cigar burned to t An ALARM CLOCK DRONES on and on from the bedroom. It fina gets turned off. BARNEY PANOFSKY (64), hung over and in his robe, lumbers down the hallway and to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the morning newspaper. Scans the front page. Something he reads upsets him.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Fuck. A SOCCER BALL rolls and stops at Barney's feet.  WHITE 10-23-09 2. JUSTIN (8) runs up and grabs the ball. He stares up at Barney. Barney stares back

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Justin, come on, we're late.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Hi Barney.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Good morning. Justin runs off. Barney turns back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now dressed, Barney reads the paper as he finishes his ba and lox. He looks at his watch -- shit, he's late. Drops the paper on the table. Puts the dishes in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER BLURB
dialogues.text: "BOOK REVIEW: Detective Sean O'Hearne writes his own acco of the scandal that rocked the city 30 years ago..." Beside the blurb is an old picture of BARNEY IN HANDCUFFS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs his cell phone and turns it on, then notices the answering machine. INSERT - BLINKING ANSWERING MACHINE: 10 MESSAGES. He presses PLAY, but only listens to the first few words each message before fast forwarding to the next.

dialogues.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE
dialogues.text: (female voice) Hi dad, I know it's early... hi dad, me again... where are you... dad, call meeee... The next few messages from an angry MALE VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad, its Michael.... Dad, I know you're there... Are you screening?... Barney turns the machine OFF. Now he can't find his keys. Scours the house for them. His cell phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT WITH KATE (24), Barney's daughter. Walking to he job as a grade school teacher, carrying a bag and thermos

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Daddy, where were you? I've been calling all morning.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: The ringer was off.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Blair had a heart attack last night.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: How bad?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Minor. He thought it was indigestion.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Putz. He finds his keys. Rushes out the door

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Dad, it's still a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney hurries down the hallway to the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: That's true. The long term effects of these things don't often show up until later. Impotence is still on the table.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Are you not at all concerned that you might have caused this?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Why would I be?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Mom told me about the phone call last night.  WHITE 10-23-09 4. That triggers a distant alcohol fogged memory. DING. The elevator arrives. He steps in.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'll call you back. I'm stepping in the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You better. Barney grins from ear to ear, filled with glee at this ne On the elevator doors closing we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney driving his Mercedes, back on the phone with Kate is approaching the school she teaches at.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I may have accidentally dialed their number.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Sure, dad. But you do have an out - it seems that Blair was already having chest pains when you called but he didn't want to bother mom with it. It was your call that woke her, and she then insisted on taking him to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: So I saved his life.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: My hero.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Did you see the paper today?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I did. Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm fine. (beat) I'll call you later.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Okay. Love you.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Love you too.  WHITE 10-23-09 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney drives up to the offices of TOTALLY UNNECESSARY PRODUCTIONS and pulls into his personal parking spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We drop right into a scene of Barney's TV show, the long running soap - "O'MALLEY OF THE NORTH". The CONSTABLE, O'MALLEY, mid-50's and still handsome, is being tended to by a female NURSE played by SOLANGE (52), making a "house call" to the local bar.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: (wrapping a bandage) How does that feel, O'Malley?

dialogues.speaker: O'MALLEY
dialogues.text: Warm and tight. SOLANGE, originally cast as the "sexpot" of the show, her uniform is inappropriately low cut and tight for a woman age, but she works it like she's still the cat's meow. Barney quietly walks onto the sound stage, and sits in hi producers chair. The scene is painful for him watch. He pulls over a WARDROBE GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Can we do something about her outfit?

dialogues.speaker: WARDROBE GIRL
dialogues.text: I tried. She has them altered herself.

dialogues.speaker: CUT
dialogues.text: (to Barney) How was that?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Appallingly bad.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Great. MOVING ON. Solange's bright smile instantly sours as she eyes Barney

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: I want to talk to you! Barney immediately hustles himself away.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't you run away from me! She tries to go after him but is stopped by the sound guy who needs to remove her mic. FOUR EXECUTIVES descend upon him, struggling to keep pace including MARK (40). Everyone talking over each other

dialogues.speaker: MARK EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: Did you see today's We need to go over the paper? opening for next week's episode.

dialogues.speaker: MARK EXECUTIVE
dialogues.text: The teaser is a minute And we lost the location long- - so we have to rewrite it for the studio-- Barney pushes through a door, leading everyone into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rows of desks occupied by accountants, story editors assistants. Barney whisks through the aisles - everyone still hot on his tail.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (announcing to entire office) Good morning everyone. Yes I've seen today's paper, no I don't give a flying fuck and neither should you, let that be the end of it.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Barney, the network wants to make a really big deal about the 30th season.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: That's in a year.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: They're looking ahead, and they're open to renewing for two more seasons. (nervous) But they have a few suggestions.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: How long have you worked for me?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Eighteen years.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: So why do you still act like a girl asking permission for a sleepover? Tell me what the hell it is. Barney heads into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exec's all follow inside and stand in silence. Mark steps forward as Barney flips through mail on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: They want to bring in a new face. Someone young. Maybe give Solange a sexy, young niece who comes to live with her--

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: They want to fire Solange?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: They want us to write her down in favor of a new character

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: No. No way.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: We'll do it in a classy way--

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I won't humiliate her like that. She's been on the show since day one. I'll give her your job before that happens.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: They're not asking. If we don't do it, this is our last season. No one under fifty watches the show.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: So they want to bring in some tits and ass?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Isn't that why you first hired her? Solange suddenly bursts through the crowd of Exec's and s a FOLDER down on Barney's desk.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: I want a word with you NOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney opens the folder and scans the papers inside.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What language is this?

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: They're from Bulgaria. Press clippings about me and they just keep coming. They love me over there. This proves what I'm really worth to the foreign market. Barney tosses the folder aside.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'll give it my utmost attention.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: I hired a new lawyer, a real shark and he says--

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, Solange, why do we need to bring lawyers into this? Solange turns around and pushes the Exec's out.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: Out! I want to talk Barney alone.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: Barney, we have to discuss--

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: She slams the door on them and turns to Barney. instantly softens.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I feel like everyone is laughing at me. Tell me honestly, how do I look? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You look like the reason we're still on the air. Sexy as hell.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: (teary) Thank you. (beat) But you're still going to pay me what I deserve. Her tone  WHITE 10-23-09 9. She stops just before exiting.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I saw the paper. How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Fine. Not wanting to get into it, Barney busies himself with mo around papers. Solange takes the cue, then takes a deep breath, puts her game face on and storms out, slamming th door behind her for effect.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BARNEY'S CAR
dialogues.text: Barney drives through downtown Montreal, eventually parki in front of Grumpy's Bar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney walks into his regular watering hole - GRUMPY'S BA The bar spotted with regulars who mumble hello to him. JILL THE BARTENDER serves him his usual.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: You get home okay last night?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I got home. With a glance, Jill directs Barney down the bar.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: He's had more than a few already. DETECTIVE SEAN O'HEARNE, around 60, slides off his barsto Grossly overweight, blotchy salmon red complexion.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: You see that review in the paper today? Not bad. Barney ignores him. O'Hearne places a copy of the infamou book he's written "WITH FRIENDS LIKE THESE" on the bar

dialogues.speaker: O'HEARNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's for you. I even signed it. Barney opens the book - dumps a handful of peanuts on the page, POUNDS it shut with his fist, then flips it back op and starts eating from the cracked nuts.  WHITE 10-23-09 10.

dialogues.speaker: O'HEARNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why do you have to be like that? I wrote a nice little note to you. O'Hearne slides the book back over to himself and clumsil flips to his hand written inscription. He's very drunk.

dialogues.speaker: O'HEARNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "To Barney, none of this would have been possible without you. All the best, Detective Sean O'Hearne".

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: This is a big day. I thought I'd buy you a drink, share in the moment, be a "mensch", like you might say. Barney looks at O'Hearne. Marvelling at his idiocy.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: For someone who professes to hate me so much, you sure do go out of your way to come around here a lot.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: I just want to know what you did with the body already.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You really want to know? Fine. I carved him up with a chainsaw, dumped the parts in the St. Lawrence river

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: Chainsaw, my ass. You'd never have the guts to cut him up. If you won't tell me now, promise you'll at least leave me a note in your will.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: C'mon O'Hearne, you're bound to go first. Look at you - prick you with a fork on a hot summer day and you'd explode like a pan fried sausage.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: This heart will still be pumping strong when your prostate turns to marble, Panofsky.  WHITE 10-23-09 11.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Why don't you just leave him alone already?

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: Because he got away with murder, sweetie. (looking at Barney) You screwed over everyone you ever knew or cared about, and now the whole world is going to know what a cocksucking murderer you really are. O'Hearne is right up in his face. INTENSE stare.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Your breath stinks. O'Hearne has to tear himself away before he tries to kill Barney. He slides the book back over to him.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: It's a real page turner. O'Hearne marches out. Barney's eyes reluctantly drift to the COVER PHOTO of the book INSERT - BLACK AND WHITE PHOTO CIRCA 1974, Barney with hi arm around his best friend BOOGIE.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Barney is out cavorting with his crew - over educated contemporaries living the bohemian life in Rome. Barney's Algonquin Round Table. Copious amounts of food and drink. Lively conversations overlap, as we move around a crowded table. Locals, ex-pa and plenty of girls. A few of Barney's standout friends b CEDRIC RICHARDSON, African American, actor, extremely han three fawning girls with him. LEO FASOLI, Italian bearded artist, his pants and t-shirt speckled with paint.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: ...I know that I can't just sit around and wait for something to happen. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I call up the director and tell him: "I've been offered Othello for the third straight year and I'm not going to pass it up just to play the fucking Chuck Wagon cook again. Who do I look like, Roscoe Lee Brown? "But that's how it's written" he answers. So I tell him - "Roberto, the time has come for the black man to hold a gun instead of a spatula".

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Amen!

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: And he had the role rewritten for me. I am now posse member number 4.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: To Cedric, living the lessons of the Bard: "be as great in act, as you have in thought". Everyone toasts. Barney's eyes light up as he leaps from his chair to greet --

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: Boogie/Welcome back! ! BOOGIE, Barney's best and most cherished friend. Tall and lean, he possesses a physical and intellectual magnetism that enchants everyone who meets him. He has a stunning g (THE COUNTESS) on his arm. Boogie is greeted by all and handed some wine. Cedric mak it a point to introduce himself to The Countess.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: I'm Cedric.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTESS/MARIA
dialogues.text: Maria. (flirtatious) You look familiar to me.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: I'm an actor.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I knew it. You look like a movie star.  WHITE 10-23-09 13. The Countess then slides up to Boogie, whispers something his ear, kisses him deeply, then walks off to the bathroo Her exquisite beauty silences them all.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Who is that?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Ah, the Countess. A descendant of Giuseppe Garibaldi, no less.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Where did you meet her?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Somewhere between my blackout in Lake Como and my hangover in Ste- Maxime. If you could find out AND get her name, that would be great. But enough about that, I want to hear about all of you. Leo, how was your showing at Galerie Des Points? The silence around the table indicates - "not so good".

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: His work is too bold for that crowd.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: The show was a bust. I only sold one piece - to Barney. Barney holds up the painting to show Boogie.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Barney - our very own patron of the arts. Otherwise known as our only friend with a real job. Everyone toasts.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: (to Barney) And so, my High Priest, did you get through those books I sent you?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: A few of them.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Only a few? I sent them months ago. What have you been doing with yourself?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Well, actually, I'm getting married.  WHITE 10-23-09 14.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: What?! To who?

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: To me. Boogie turns around to find CLARA CHAMBERS (26), tall, sk pale and beautiful, gypsy shawl and skirt. Three months pregnant, and slightly showing at her belly. She downs a shot of Grappa and lights a cigarette as she sits.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Prince Charmingbaum here knocked me up by way of a magical thirty seconds of friction.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Where have you been? You didn't come home last night.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Who remembers? (to Boogie) Has he told you what he's doing now? Exporting olive oil to some guy, Hymie back in Montreal. It's like a bad Jewish sitcom.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Someone needs to make a living.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: He comes to Europe and sells oil. It's fucking humiliating. You're not one of us. You're a voyeur--

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Okay, A toast to the newlyweds! To your health, your happiness- -

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: (at Barney) And a three inch prick

dialogues.speaker: L'CHAIM
dialogues.text: Everyone drinks. Barney scowls at Clara. She instantly switches gears to soft and loving.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, baby. You're still my yummy yid.  WHITE 10-23-09 15. She gets on his lap, curling herself around him like a ca He starts to soften, the party around them continues on..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closing down the bar, the whole gang pours out into the street. Barney and Boogie lead the way, sharing a flask Barney shlepping Leo's painting with him.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Why did you agree to marry her?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I got her pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: So? Clara's crazy. She's a conversation piece, not a wife. And how do you even know it's yours?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: It's mine.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: If you say so. Boogie turns to the gang: Leo pulling up the rear with hi girl. Cedric walking with one arm around Clara and the ot around the Countess, who is quite smitten with him.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what's the plan everyone? What are we doing?

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: I have an early call time tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. TI don't believe what I'm seeing.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: (lighting a cigarette) Count me out. I'm already hung over and I'm not even done being drunk yet. Oh, yeah, and I'm fucking pregnant too. C'mon, Barney.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: He's coming with me.  WHITE 10-23-09 16.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Taking him out for a proper bachelor party.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Oh no, you're not.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: You don't own him just yet. Boogie drags Barney down a side street.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Got any money?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Some. Why?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Provisions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laid out on the table in Boogie's hotel room: A bottle of Scotch, two packs of Gauloises, a pack of rol papers, a small ball of TINFOIL. Barney finds two clean glasses in the messy room and pour them each a drink. Boogie unwraps the tinfoil to reveal a ball of OPIUM inside. Then gathers his drug paraphernalia

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: We have to do it all, Barney. Opium, Horse, Hash - everything under and behind the sun, on and off the table. We only go around once. They toast and drink. Boogie then hands Barney a thick MANUSCRIPT off the floor

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You finished it?!

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Not quite yet. But you can read it so far. Barney drops onto the mattress and starts right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney has gone through a hundred pages so far

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Boogie, this is brilliant. Absolutely brilliant. When are they publishing it?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: They're not.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: I didn't submit it.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Why the hell not?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: I told you, it's not finished yet. And anyway, I'm never giving it to that feckless editor.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What about the advance they paid you?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: I wrote him another one.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Which? Boogie reaches over and tosses Barney a manuscript.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's it about? While Boogie weaves his tale, he heats up and crumbles so of the Opium, preparing to smoke it in a pipe.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: It's a new interpretation of the Book of Job, as told through Vanessa's vaginal lips. Pious and pristine Vanessa's Pussy is a pillar of religious devotion. Then one day, without warning or reason, Vanessa's Pussy is suddenly fucked over and over and over again by The Supreme Being; a deity who erects himself into this temporal world as The Great Cock. After an ungodly amount of (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: drilling, and now a shell of the hole she used to be, Vanessa's Pussy surrenders her absolute devotion to The Great Cock. As reward, her elasticity is restored, but she's left with a recurring odorous rash. (beat) For some reason the editor passed. Barney looks at him dumfounded.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Let me guess - Vanessa is the editor's wife.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Was. Boogie takes a hit off the pipe. Barney tries to stare hi down like a disapproving parent, but the sheer bravado of the story makes them both crack up.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Jesus, Boogie, stop dicking around and finish your book already. Barney pours himself more Scotch and continues reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wedding day. Boogie, Cedric, Leo accompany Barney and Cla up the steps to the Mayor's Marriage Office. Clara is seven months pregnant, wearing a black veil. Ced helps her up the stairs. Barney wears a mix and match tuxedo. He and Boogie walk ahead of the others.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Listen, you don't have to go through with this.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You're saying this to me now?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: I'm just saying, no one will think anything less of you.  WHITE 10-23-09 19.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (beat ) C'mon, we're already late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone waits for the JUDGE who looks over their paperwo (JUDGE'S DIALOGUE IS IN ITALIAN AND SUBTITLED).

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I vistri passaporti, prego The Judge takes a cursory glance and hands them to his CL

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I testimoni, prego - Bernardo Moscovitz, Leonardo Fasoli. Boogie and Leo step forward and sign the marriage license

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Barney Panofsky, firmi qui. Barney signs.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Clara Charnofksy, firmi qui.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (in bad Italian) Charnofsky? No, is chiama Clara Chambers.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Non secondo il suo passaporto. Clara says nothing. Barney grabs her passport to see for himself.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: I was married to a Russian gangster for maybe five days. I ran away on the honeymoon. I just never bothered to do the paperwork to change the name back.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Did you not think to mention this?

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Don't worry, you still got yourself a true blue Shiksa.  WHITE 10-23-09 20.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What else haven't you told me? Any kids I don't know about?

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Only two - Yosel and Chaim. They're locked in our attic. When you're out getting the hockey scores I let them down and force feed them pork roast milkshakes through a funnel. Dumfounded silence. Then -- Clara SNATCHES the pen from Barney's hand and signs the license in a flash.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: CEDRIC
dialogues.text: (beat) Mazel Tov!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THUNDER and LIGHTENING rage outside. Barney holds Clara in his arms as she is curled on the be clutching her black wedding veil, trembling with white kn fear; a child terrified of the thunder. All around the apartment we see scraps of half written po sketches and paintings.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. (beat) You still love your crazy Clara, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (beat) Of course. (beat) Can I get you anything? You haven't eaten a thing all day.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Maybe a piece of fruit. Barney reaches over and hands her a BANANA off the table. Clara begins to peel it from the WRONG END.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Why do you peel it like that?  WHITE 10-23-09 21.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: I read somewhere this is how monkeys do it. I figured they should know. She may be crazy, but she has her odd charms. Barney hold her tight as she flinches at another rumble of thunder

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney runs through the halls of the hospital in Rome, frantically demanding help from the nurse's desk.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (to Nurse, in Italian) I need to find my wife - Clara Panofsky. Or Chambers. Or maybe Charnofsky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DOCTOR sits down, lights up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Signor Panofsky - mi dispiace - I will speak in English. I am afraid the infant was a stillborn. Barney is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But your wife is healthy and will certainly be able to bear other children. (beat) I must ask if you know the biological father - for our records.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm the father. The doctor looks at Barney incredulously, then to his cha than back at Barney.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Then you must be an Albino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney enters and sits at Clara's bedside. She's sketchin a picture of Barney on a pad as they talk. Barney won't look her in the eye.  WHITE 10-23-09 22.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Every four hours they attach clamps to my nipples and milk me like a cow. (beat) I was sure it was yours--

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Can we talk about this later? Barney is visibly hurt and angry. Clara strokes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Oh Barney, you really do wear your heart on your sleeve. (beat) Now put it away, it's disgusting to look at.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (up and leaving) I'll pick you up tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: I'm not going to let you divorce me! Barney is already out the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney walks down the hallway where his friends are gathe and looking somber. The Countess and Leo are consoling Cedric. Barney makes a bee-line for Cedric and SUCKER PUN him. Boogie jumps in and wrestles Barney away from Cedric

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Easy, man. C'mon. He just lost a son. Barney looks at Boogie - "what the fuck?". With an incredulous grunt, he walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney helps Clara out of a taxi and into their apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney helps Clara onto the bed, pours her a glass of wat

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm ready to talk now. Barney waits.  WHITE 10-23-09 23.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've already spoken with a lawyer. If you divorce me I'm entitled to half your income for the rest of your life.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Clara, I never knew you had such a practical streak in you.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Surprise. Not all us Shiksa's are chumps. (lights a cigarette) Look, I'm not a pig despite what you might think. I'll settle for a year's rent on this dump and an allowance of fifty dollars a week.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'll move out tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Oh look, the color's come back into your cheeks. Now you can finally go back home, tongue your way into proper society and find yourself a nice Jewish girl - someone who shops.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (grabbing a few clothes) As always, your insight is dazzling.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Come now, I did you a great favor. You'll be able to entertain them all at the United Jewish Appeal galas with stories about Crazy Clara Chambers before she got famous. Now get the hell out while I try and rustle up a proper fuck. Barney walks out and never looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clara runs out and screams down the stairwell after Barne

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Wait! I'm sorry, Barney! Let's start over! Please, Barney! Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney is aggressively chopping vegetables as he prepares food. Boogie crumples some hash to roll in a joint.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: My uncle Irv offered to get me into TV production. He says there's all these tax loopholes in Canada that make it foolproof.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Pass the lighter off the table. Barney reaches for the lighter. He sees an ENVELOPE addre to him. He opens it and pulls out a HANDWRITTEN NOTE:

dialogues.speaker: CLARA'S VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Barney, Please come for dinner tonight at eight. I think it's important we talk. I'm sorry. I really do miss you. I need you. I'll even make latkes. Yours, Clara.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: When did this come?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: What? Oh, that. Shit. Sorry, I forgot. I think it came a few days ago. Barney looks at Boogie with disgust, throwing the lighter him on his way out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney runs up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney rushes in and finds a table set for a candlelight dinner for two. The candles completely burned away.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Clara? He slowly moves through the apartment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A charred chicken and a tray of latkes out on the stove.  WHITE 10-23-09 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Clara lies dead on the bed. An empty bottle of slee pills at her side. Her sketches and poetry scattered all over the room. Barney drops to her, feels for a pulse. Nothing. His eyes well up with tears...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANNING OVER soiled laundry, empty wine bottles, ashtrays the abstract painting of Leo's... to a hung over Barney, snoozing on the sofa, wakening to a POUNDING on the door. Rising unsteadily, Barney climbs over packed cartons labe "Clara's poetry, Clara's Sketches, Clara's Paintings". He opens the door. CHARNOFSKY (50), stands there. An Orthodox Jew, black hat black wool coat and a Van Dyke beard. His tie has been ne rent (cut) with scissors.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Are you here about the apartment?

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFKSY
dialogues.text: I'm Chaim Charnofsky.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: The Russian?

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFKSY
dialogues.text: Brighton Beach. I'm Clara's father Your machuten. Are you going to invite me in? Still in a haze, Barney steps to the side. Hands clasped behind his back, Charnofsky wanders in, studying the apartment. He is immediately drawn to a specific INK SKET The completed sketch Clara started in the hospital: Barne drawn to look like Satan, along with a group of demons ravishing a pregnant young woman who looks much like Clar

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFKSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who would buy such a disgusting thing?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Actually, Clara made it. (beat) She said her parents were dead.  WHITE 10-23-09 26.

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFKSY
dialogues.text: She's been saying that since she was ten. (looking Barney over) So you're the one she married? (off Barney's nod) I understand there was a child.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: We lost him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFKSY
dialogues.text: So you lost a son and I lost a daughter. May there be no more mourning in your house or mine. (beat) You have a bisel Schnapps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney pours them each a Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFKSY
dialogues.text: I'm the Cantor of the B'Nai Jacob synagogue. It's not a princely living, but they provide us with an apartment. (looking at boxes) Clara's things?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Her notebooks. Poems, diaries, ink drawings. People think highly of her work. You should have a publisher look at them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFKSY
dialogues.text: Diaries, you said? Filth about me and her mother, I'm sure. Ship them to my nephew. He's a professor of literature at NYU. He used to encourage her. Charnofsky finishes his drink. Pours himself another

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFKSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can imagine the guilt you're carrying right now, but you should know this wasn't the first time my Clara tried to kill herself. It all started when she was twelve. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFKSY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tearing her hair out in clumps, "I'm not Jewish", "you're not my parents" she'd scream. She would refuse to eat, we'd have to force feed her chicken soup through a funnel, then she would vomit all over me on purpose. She'd run away for days and sneak black boys into the house so the whole neighborhood could see. My wife wanted to die. That's when I started locking her in the attic. She was a danger to everyone. My wife would bring her food, leave it outside the door. Once she goes to collect the dishes and lets out a shriek - you know why? Clara left a number two on the plate.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: She was obviously sick.

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFSKY
dialogues.text: You're telling me? We went to Dr. Kupner. The Head Rabbi's son-in- law, went to Harvard, the best in town. You think Clara was grateful? "He felt up my tits" she would scream in front of everyone at the hospital. It was a horror.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I think you should leave.

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFSKY
dialogues.text: What? I've upset you?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFSKY
dialogues.text: You dare speak to me that way? After all my wife and I endured for that child. We did everything we could, but only God determines the outcome.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: God didn't lock a sick child in the attic. God didn't place his daughter in the hands of a molester then apologize for any embarrassment she may have caused him.  WHITE 10-23-09 28.

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFSKY
dialogues.text: You act all high and mighty with me?! Barney takes hold of his arm and frog-marches him to the door and out into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFSKY
dialogues.text: You couldn't have made her so happy either or she wouldn't have done that to herself.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFSKY
dialogues.text: The man at the embassy told me she was dead two days before you found her. Two days! Where were you her loving husband?! An irate Barney takes a menacing step toward him.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Get out NOW. Charnofsky scrambles down the stairs, yelling back at Bar

dialogues.speaker: CHARNOFSKY
dialogues.text: Murderer, oysvorf, mamzer. I wish makkes on you and your unborn children!

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO PRESENT DAY.
dialogues.text: Barney stirring a pot of boiling pasta. It's ready. Turns the burner off. Pulls out a STRAINER from a cupboard. He pauses for a moment, looking at the strainer quizzical He grabs the phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL (26), Barney's son, in his Brooklyn loft. Sparsel decorated and immaculate except for his cluttered work ar filled with papers and stacks upon stacks of books.  WHITE 10-23-09 29.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Hi dad.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What do you call that thing you use for pasta...?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm holding it in my goddamn hand - the thing to strain pasta...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: A strainer?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: The other word.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Colander.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: COLANDER. See, this is what you have to look forward to. Barney prepares his pasta as he talks. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: This is why you called?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: And to say hello.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I read online that O'Hearne's book finally came out.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I heard about that.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: How is it?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: How would I know? I wouldn't read that garbage.  WHITE 10-23-09 30. Barney shuts O'Hearne's book, which we now see was open a dog-eared on the counter Just then, Michael's fiancee CAROLINE (28) comes home. A young lawyer in a power suit. She flips off her heels, gi him a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: (whisper ) Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: My dad. Caroline sneers.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad, I have to go, Caroline just got home. She says hi.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: No she doesn't. How's the thesis coming along?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It's not, but I did find a title: "The colonialist racial ideologies of Western modernism in Bellow's work".

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Catchy.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thanks. I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Sure. Michael hangs up. MOVE WITH BARNEY as he carries his bowl of pasta out to t BAR where he fixes himself a Scotch. After pouring his drink he pauses for a moment to stare a one of the many personal photos hanging behind the bar When he walks away WE REMAIN ON THE PHOTO he was looking In Black & White - Barney and his uncle IRV NUSSBAUM posi at a Fundraiser for Israel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney is in the office of his uncle, IRV NUSSBAUM (60). While Irv is on the phone, Barney peruses a wall of PLAQU dedicated to Irv for his efforts in supporting Israel.

dialogues.speaker: IRV
dialogues.text: (into phone) --Abe, you know what happened last night? Some nazi punks took a shit right on the steps of the Beth Zion... that's right. That's why you can't get complacent with your support - we need Israel. I don't have to tell you where things like this lead to - it starts with a turd, next thing we're wearing arm bands again... (nodding)... wonderful, oh and you're coming for dinner this Friday, right? Great. Irv hangs up, pleased as punch.

dialogues.speaker: IRV., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Donations go through the roof when shit like this happens. Let's eat. Irv gets up and exits. Barney follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irv leads Barney through the factory.

dialogues.speaker: IRV
dialogues.text: I'm going to trust you with a few pledge cards to begin with. You do good for Israel, good will come your way. Now, the rules of the game: Never visit your target in the office where he's king shit and you're just another shmuck looking for a handout. You lure the lion out with meat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch time. Black tie waiters carry big juicy steaks, col slaw, and pickles to businessmen in booths.

dialogues.speaker: IRV
dialogues.text: --And no one does meat like Moishe's. Irv shakes hands with practically every big wig having lu

dialogues.speaker: TWO NEW YORK STEAKS
dialogues.text: Which are brought to Irv and Barney, now seated.

dialogues.speaker: IRV
dialogues.text: This is my table. You sit here, nowhere else. I'll give you the target's annual income. Not the numbers on his tax returns - the real numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney having steak with ROBERT LANTOS. Barney looks a li green around the collar.

dialogues.speaker: IRV, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: --You slam dunk him on the Holocaust. It could happen here, you tell him. Israel is our insurance policy.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (to Target 1) It could happen here. Israel is our insurance policy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney with TARGET 2. He's getting a little more comforta

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: It could happen here. Israel is our insurance policy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney with TARGET 3. Barney's sporting a good haircut an a nice suit. He's getting the hang of this.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Who's to say it couldn't happen here? Israel is our insurance policy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney's holding court a group of big wigs which include the TARGETS and ROBERT LANTOS. He's certainly found his stride in 'proper' society.  WHITE 10-23-09 33.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: --And I hate to say it, but it could happen here.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET 3
dialogues.text: Absolutely, we get that, but tell Marv about the TV deal.

dialogues.speaker: TARGET 2
dialogues.text: Is it a good show?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT LANTOS
dialogues.text: It's a mound of shit but it's the best goddamn tax shelter I've ever had.

dialogues.speaker: IRV
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I need to borrow my nephew for a moment. Irv escorts Barney away.

dialogues.speaker: IRV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What did I tell you, boychick? Fundraising, producing, it's all the same dance. Now listen, I got a girl I want you to meet.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Irv, I don't need to be set up.

dialogues.speaker: IRV
dialogues.text: Listen, this girl's got it all - comes from a VERY good family, she has a master's from McGill, and she's a real looker. Sit. Irv taps the shoulder of THE SECOND MRS. P (30). The ulti 'JAP'. Cute, voluptuous, stylishly dressed.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: You must be Barney. Irv's told me all about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney and The Second Mrs. P sit in a corner away from th rest of the guests. They're hitting it off.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --throughout the entire second year of my master's degree I kept having the same recurring dream where I'm 16 again, standing in Reuben's Butchershop on St. Viateur wearing my hair ina pigtail tied with this velvet ribbon (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: my Aunt Sarah got me from Saks -- Did you know Reuben? He was such a card. When I was ten he'd come around from behind the counter and ask "how come a beauty like you isn't married yet?" - So it's true your father is really a cop? That's why you're not a square like most of the Jewish boys I meet -- what are you smiling about? You're a little devil aren't you... Her grating qualities aside, she is sexy and the picture perfect Jewish wife. Maybe Irv's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney and IZZY (60), his father, walk up the steep steps Izzy's carrying a bottle of Scotch for a gift.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: So, dad, remember, watch the language and mind the manners.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I got it, kid. Don't worry. They reach the door. Barney rings the bell. The door open

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Dad, that's the housekeeper. A short, Polish housekeeper, stares at them coldly.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Swanky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classical music. The gentle tinkling of silver cutlery on fine china. Dinner with the soon to be IN-LAWS - the WASPiest Jews yo ever seen. It's clear they are far from happy about this union. Everyone eats in horribly awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Mr. Panofsky, I bet you have a lot of interesting stories, having been a detective and all.  WHITE 10-23-09 35.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Please, gorgeous, call me Izzy. And I was just a beat cop. Jews don't get promoted to detective in this town.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER-IN-LAW
dialogues.text: Have you encountered anti-semitism in your profession?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: What do you think? Let me give you an example: One of my first shifts on the job, I corner four guys doing a dope deal in an alley. Big score for a rookie. I call for backup "cuz the rules say you can only put three in a patrol car, and I'm trying to play it by the book. You think they send anyone to help? The dispatcher says to me: "your people are good with numbers - you figure it out". So I toss three in the back, throw the fourth across the hood, handcuff him to the side-view mirror, then haul ‘em all in.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER- IN-LAW
dialogues.text: Oh my God, that's so dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Only when he blocked my view.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER-IN-LAW
dialogues.text: I meant for him.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: You can't be soft with these degenerates.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER- IN-LAW
dialogues.text: Are you saying you were gratuitously violent with suspected felons?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Gratuitously? I always got paid, I ain't gonna work for free.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: He means unnecessarily.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Look, when a feller is young and you give him authority, he likes to push (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: IZZY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: people around. But I had to be extra careful because I knew my name was Panofsky. And most of the time I was.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER- IN-LAW
dialogues.text: Most? Did you ever consider that maybe your career advancement was stunted by your professional conduct and not by imagined prejudices?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I call it like I see it. I wore my name on my badge for everyone to see and all I ever did was walk the beat. But you're the one with the mansion on the hill, so what do I know? (to Second Mrs. P) You got brains from him and beauty from her - what a sweet little casserole you are. Let's make a toast. Izzy, Barney and The Second Mrs. P raises their glasses. The In-Laws don't even reach for theirs.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To the blessed match of our lovebirds. You never know what tomorrow brings. So get to shtupping and multiply already. Under the table Mrs. P squeezes Barney high up his leg. Barney flinches, then drinks along with Izzy and Mrs. P. The In-Laws set their glasses back down without sipping. Everyone continues eating.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This chicken is great. Cutlery tinkling...

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER-IN-LAW
dialogues.text: It's fish.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CAR
dialogues.text: Barney driving Boogie from the airport. Boogie looks like he hasn't slept for days.  WHITE 10-23-09 37.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I was starting to think you weren't going to show up. It's been two months since I last heard from you.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Has it really? Shit, have I got stories for you.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: That, I have no doubt of.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Listen, man, are you sure you want to go through with this? We can turn around and be on a flight to Rome in a few hours - no questions asked. Lunch at Dal Bolognese on me.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: C'mon, you haven't even met her yet. Anyway, I have two tickets in the reds to the Stanley Cup game tonight. Do you think after the dinner I can slip out to catch the third period?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: I don't know. Brides tend to be a little touchy about things like that.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 300 guests. A huge affair. The band is ripping it up thro a raucous HORA that carries over the following moments: Barney and his mates do the Hora the way it should be don THE SECOND MRS. P SQUEALING and BARNEY feeling queasy as they are HOISTED up and down on chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN ARMY OF SERVERS burst forth from the kitchen carrying entrees. PLATES LAND at various tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bride's side of the family all prim and proper -- The Second Mrs. P talking with her mother --  WHITE 10-23-09 38.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER-IN-LAW
dialogues.text: Darling, I just have to tell you again how gorgeous you look. And did you see how Marsha was looking at you?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Did I ever? Poison from her eyes she was so jealous. Do you remember her dress? She looked like a futon. IZZY making eyes at a curvaceous woman with a plunging neckline -- Father-In-Law watching Izzy with disdain but Maintaining a polite smile for appearances. His gaze is then drawn further down the table by -- BOOGIE, LEO AND CEDRIC toasting him.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE/LEO/CEDRIC
dialogues.text: Mazel Tov!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAND playing an upbeat number for a jam-packed dancef Barney slips out from the crowd and races to the bar -- CU - A BLACK & WHITE TV hidden behind the bar showing the hockey game.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What's the score?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: One - zip. Bruins just scored.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Shit. Barney downs another shot, then looks back to the dancefl where he sees IZZY slow dancing with The Second Mrs. P.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: --I was denied the first time I tried to get on the force because I was too goddamn short, then I learned you had to clip a hundred dollar bill to your application. Suddenly, I was tall, dark and handsome enough.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Well, dark and handsome you most certainly are.  WHITE 10-23-09 39.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Oh boy, did my Barney ever luck out with you.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Oh, Izzy. It's me who's the lucky one.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Sunshine, from where I'm standing, trust me, he's the lucky one. Izzy grins and lays his head and her ample bosom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boogie emerges from behind the band, wiping his nose from having just done a hit of coke. He joins Barney, Izzy and friends at the bar watching the game.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BAR
dialogues.text: Everyone ROARS at a near miss.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY/BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Go Habs! Come on! They all do a round of shots. Then more shots. And more shots. His FATHER IN LAW watching in disgust. The Second Mrs. P lunges onto him from out of nowhere--

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Barney! Your father is sitting with the Rabbi! Go to do something quick! She SHOVES him toward the table.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI'S TABLE
dialogues.text: The Rabbi and the other guests are visibly horrified by I anecdotes. Irv, knowing Izzy, loves every minute of it.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: --so we're shaking down a rub and tug - I never bust the girls, they provide a valuable service - but we do it for appearances. Anyway, we're doing our thing and one of the clients - some crazy Hungarian Nazi loaded on Slivovitz starts going ape shit - he comes at me with a chair, butt naked with a hard-on like a can of hairspray--  WHITE 10-23-09 40.

dialogues.speaker: IRV
dialogues.text: Iz, maybe you should tone it down a little.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: What, like they've never heard about such things?

dialogues.speaker: RABBI
dialogues.text: Mr. Panosfky, there are ladies present.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: C'mon Rabbi, everyone knows The Almighty tests the Jewish man with two great temptations: shiksas and bacon.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Dad, can I steal you away for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Don't anybody move. I'll be right back. As Barney escorts Izzy away, the ENTIRE TABLE, except for Irv, disperses.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Nice bunch of folks here tonight. I thought they'd all be snobby but I'm actually having a hell of a time. What are you laughing at?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Come here. Barney gives his father a big hug. At this moment he coul love him more. But then...

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad, what's in your pocket?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I almost forgot. Izzy takes Barney to a quiet corner

dialogues.speaker: IZZY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your wedding present. From inside his jacket, Izzy pulls out a GUN In Hanukkah wrapping paper.  WHITE 10-23-09 41.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My first gun. I want you to have it.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Say thank you and get us a drink

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Thank you. They walk to the bar. Slide out their glasses for refills

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Your father-in-law said that neither of you was to have any more to drink Barney grabs a bottle himself and refills their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Where is that asshole?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Barney, don't embarrass me. Barney stomps off, pushing through the crowd. Gets his fa in law in his sights. Just as he is about to reach him, something catches his eye that stops him in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ACROSS THE ROOM - MIRIAM GRANT (28), Gorgeous, classy, striking eyes. Barney is mesmerized.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER IN LAW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Barney? Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Uh, no, forget it... Barney turns away, but then cuts right back --

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't ever tell my father what he can or cannot do again.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER IN LAW
dialogues.text: He traumatized the Rabbi's wife--

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I don't care if he fingered her under the table. He's my father and he'll have your respect.  WHITE 10-23-09 42. Father-In-Law is speechless. And Barney sets out again for Miriam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He emerges from a cluster of guests and spots Miriam. She chatting with a HANDSOME YOUNG MAN (JEFF) who excuses him and goes to the bar. Barney walks right up to her.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: We haven't met yet. I'm Barney.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I'm Miriam. Thank you for having me. Barney is like a nervous and awkward teenager, not to men really drunk.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Fine. Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I understand you're in television.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Totally Unnecessary Productions.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: That's a little harsh.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: That's the name of my company. She laughs. That's something he can never tire of. Miriam notices the UNLIT cigar he's holding.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Your cigar is out.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Oh, that's okay, I wouldn't want it to bother you.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Please, It's a Montecristo. She grabs a box of matches from the table. As she lights his cigar and talks it's as if the whole world around him has disappeared. The entire moment incredibly intimate.  WHITE 10-23-09 43.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know why they're called Montecristo's?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Not a clue.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Fine cigars are all still rolled by hand. The workers who perform this task are called "torcedores", and they all chip in from their own wages to employ 'lectors' - people who read them stories as they work. Entertainment to make the day pass better. At the factory which produces this Montecristo, the workers favorite story was, you guessed it, the Count of said name.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Lectors.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Nice touch, don't you think? He's utterly smitten. Over her shoulder he spots the Bartender waving to get his attention the score now 1-1.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Nothing. The hockey game.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Who's winning?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Habs just tied it up. You follow hockey?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: No, but I do read newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Are you doing anything later? Wwe can still catch the flight to Rome. Lunch at Dal Bolognese on the Piazza del Popolo.  WHITE 10-23-09 44.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: The bride may take issue with that. Anyway, I have to catch my train back to New York later She nods, and with perfect manners, rises and extends her

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Congratulations again. He stands, takes her hand and would never let go if she d take it back. He stares at her walking away until--

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Barney? The Second Mrs. P directly behind him.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: I see you met Miriam. She's sucha snob that one, don't you find?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah - sure - no - why?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: She went to McGill with me, works in radio now. The kind who subscribes to The Economist then buys Vogue off the stand. Now come explain to Judy and Leon that you don't make pornography.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Barney downs yet another Scotch. His tie loose around his neck, he's drunk and looks miserable. Boogie sits beside him, wiping his sniffling, coked-up nose.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Thanks for being here, Boogie.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: I'll never miss any of your weddings. They knock glasses.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, I almost forgot. Boogie rifles through his pockets then hands Barney a NOT  WHITE 10-23-09 45.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Classy dame. Smart as a whip too.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Who? Boogie points Barney across the room to MIRIAM. She has h coat on and is walking out with the Handsome Young Man.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Boogie, for the first time in my life I am truly, seriously, irretrievably in love. The Second Mrs. P appears behind him, draping her arms ar his neck.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Oh Barney, so am I. So am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney darts out of the Ritz Hotel and jumps into a taxi. It's raining. Cars are honking, people pouring out into t streets to celebrate their Hockey team's victory. Traffic is at a standstill so Barney hops back out and decides to by foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney, soaking wet, sprints down the stairs into the sta He sees the FLASHING LIGHT indicating the entrance to the NEW YORK CITY PLATFORM, where a porter is checking passen tickets. Thinking fast on his feet, Barney hurtles down t UPWARD rolling escalator to sneak onto the platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney makes his way through the train, passing from car car, looking for Miriam... whom he finally spots. She's wearing her reading glasses, engrossed in a novel. Barney takes a moment just to watch her. Just being able look at her makes him feel good. He drops into the seat next to her. She's stunned.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I like you with glasses. She takes them off. Shuts her book - Herzog by Saul Bello  WHITE 10-23-09 46.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?!

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Run away with me.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Run away with me, or stay with me, or I'll go with you--

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind?!

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm heels over head, bent over backwards in love with you--

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Leaving Montreal in two minutes!

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: How can you say you're in love with me? We just met - on your WEDDING NIGHT. Barney grins from ear to ear, overtaken by an unfamiliar sense of euphoria.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This isn't funny! Get off this train right now. Every word he says - every breath between every word - completely sincere and sober:

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I can't believe this really happens. It really does, just like that. And I don't care if it happened on my wedding night, at a funeral, on my death bed. It's happened. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I.D., tickets. Miriam hands over her documents to the conductor

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I don't have I.D. or a ticket.  WHITE 10-23-09 47.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: Then you'll have to get off the train.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Go home, Barney. Among other things, sobriety and regret are anxiously waiting up for you. Barney finally concedes. He stands - the train LURCHES forward as it begins to pull out.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You look fantastic in that dress. Barney gets off the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney runs along with the train as it picks up speed. Mi sits at the window, but won't look at him. But then her eyes turn to Barney, watching him still chas after her, unconcerned with how utterly foolish he appear and she smiles at him. That smile is enough to melt his heart. He runs faster - into a flat-out sprint trying to get back on and then-- TRIPS and falls HARD onto the concrete platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens revealing Barney - he's a mess. Ripped pan bloody knee and palms.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER IN LAW
dialogues.text: We thought you were dead. Whether that was concern or hope is unclear. Barney steps inside. The Second Mrs. P runs out and wraps herself around him.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Oh my God, are you okay? We thought you were dead!! We called the police, the hospitals, I was so ferklempt Dr. Stein gave me a half a Valium-- THUD. Everyone falls silent. THE GUN has fallen out of Barney's jacket onto the floor. Oops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On their honeymoon, Barney and The Second Mrs. P are walk through the shopping district adjacent to the Spanish Ste The Second Mrs. P trying to manage a huge fold-out map of Rome. Barney is morose and ill-tempered.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Could you put that away please? It's our honeymoon not a travel junket.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: I'm embarrassing you?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Like with the bidet?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You didn't have to ask the concierge. I could have told you what it was for.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Do you have a Masters degree?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Am I embarrassed? She stares him down for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Snap out of it. We came to Rome to have fun not mourn the death of your first wife. She yanks him into a LINGERIE STORE. That perks him up slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Second Mrs. P models her acquisitions for a bored Bar as she talks long distance to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: (into phone) --Ma, you should see the bathrobes we've got here, and the soaps are to (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: die for... Of course I will, I've already stuffed three bars in my suitcase for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Second Mrs. P cuts the labels off her designer clothe while on the phone to her mother. Barney lays on the bed reading the sports section of the International Herald Tr

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: (into phone) --It's from Dior. I wore it today and boy did I turn a lot of heads. I'm going to wear it to temple on the high holidays. Arlene will die on the spot... Barney only likes going shopping when I'm buying lingerie... What's wrong with that? Would you prefer he be like cousin Cyril?... Ma, they banned Cyril from the men's locker room at the Y.M.H.A... I'm just saying... Okay, sure, I'll talk to you tomorrow. Okay, tell Daddy I love him, I'll talk to you tomorrow. She hangs up and starts putting away the day's purchases.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I was just thinking about the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: It was beautiful wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Lots of relatives.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Well, we do have a big family.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You certainly do. (beat) Who was that guy from Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: My cousin Isaac?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Right. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And what about that girl, I think she was from New York, the one in the blue dress...

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Miriam Grant.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Right. Who was she again?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: She was a few years behind me at McGill. I didn't even invite her. My cousin Jeff brought her. She gets onto the bed beside him.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Jeff seems gay.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Jeff is gay. He just pretends for the family.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Oh good. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Good?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (covering) Better he should live a lie than inconvenience your family. (gets under bedspread) I'm going to take a quick nap before dinner.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Nap? I don't think so. The Second Mrs. P slides underneath the covers and starts going down -- but then POPS back up.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you wash it like I asked?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: With soap?  WHITE 10-23-09 51.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Okay. She dives back under and starts in again. It's like endur a highly invasive procedure.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO PRESENT DAY.
dialogues.text: Hurrying down the street, Barney passes a BOOKSTORE where new biography of CLARA CHAMBERS is prominently featured i the window display. The familiar ink drawing she made of Barney drawn as Satan, gracing its cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KATE is already waiting in line. Barney squeezes through the crowd, accidentally bumping the young woman standing behind them without apologizing. We'll call her ORGANI-GI

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Sorry, I'm late. I took a cab.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: That's okay, I just got here.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: And how are you, my favorite offspring?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: To tell you the truth - perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: By what?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: By you. (to cashier) Two double espressos. (to Barney) You do something awful, but instead of trying to make up for it, you opt for something infinitely worse.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  WHITE 10-23-09 52.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Are you kidding?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm really not.

dialogues.speaker: ORGANI -GIRL
dialogues.text: (leaning in) My father does the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Doesn't it make you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: ORGANI-GIRL
dialogues.text: They just don't listen to anything--

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (to Organi-Girl) Hey, flaxseed - this - is not going to happen. No crazies today. (to Kate) Continue.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Dad, before the recent phone incident you got Blair a subscription to "Boy Toy" monthly using his work address. Before that, you signed him up to an Al-Queda website. The man still can't fly out of the country.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I've upset Claire, haven't I?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You've upset Mom. Blair is too much of a chicken shit to say anything.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (kissing her cheek) You are truly my proudest achievement. They get their coffees and walk to the door.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: My point is, it's time to lay off Blair.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: He stole her from me.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: No he didn't. You got divorced. She got remarried.  WHITE 10-23-09 53.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: There was no one rooting for a comeback more than I was, but it's time to let it go. They're happily married. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: They're married. Stick to the facts.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: An apology wouldn't hurt either.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Apologize to who? Kate gives up.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don't you come up to the cottage this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Actually, I have a date.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Nice boy?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: No, he's a nasty piece of work.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Funny.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: He's very nice. We'll see. It's our third date and I'm not bored silly or madly in love. I like him. I think that's a sign of maturity. Barney stops walking. Looks around. Confused.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Where did I park my car?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You took a cab.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Right. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (laughing it off) Well, I definitely need a weekend in the country.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BARNEY'S CAR
dialogues.text: Barney drives out of the city. The gorgeous Montreal skyl behind him.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BARNEY'S CAR
dialogues.text: Barney drives along a country road toward his cottage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney is relaxing on the deck of his lakeside cottage. A Montecristo, Macallan's, reading "THE LIFE OF HEINRICH HE A RUSTLING comes from the woods. Barney looks up but it's pitch black out there. Probably a squirrel. Something RUSTLES again, this time a little closer. Barne stands, leans on the wood railing, trying to see through darkness. Waiting for something to appear. Hoping. From a distance, he hears the faint sound of a TWIN ENGIN AIRPLANE approaching. The sound carries over to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young Solange is acting in a scene staged in an obvious fake mock-up of an AIRPLANE COCKPIT SET. We now see why s was originally hired; she's a total knockout. Wearing a tight, low cut outfit, she's tending to O'MALLE who has a small cut on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: O'MALLEY
dialogues.text: Thank you, nurse.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: Thank you for landing us safely, Constable.

dialogues.speaker: O'MALLEY
dialogues.text: Hopefully the weather will be more forgiving next time I pass through.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: Well you can be sure my landing strip will be cleared for you.  WHITE 10-23-09 55.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: CUT! Great, turning around! Solange immediately bursts into tears. The crew go about their business.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Barney) What's wrong with Solange?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Her fiancee died in a plane crash.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: That was over a year ago. Look at her, you'd think it just--

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: To let you finish that thought would be an insult to stupidity.

dialogues.speaker: PRODUCTION ASSISTANT
dialogues.text: Barney, there's a call for you. A Miriam Grant-- Barney BOLTS from his chair.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Miriam?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam closes the door to a tiny office for privacy.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Barney, this has to stop.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You got my flowers?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I got the flowers, and the gifts - every week it's something else. I don't know where to start with how inappropriate all this is.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Just skip ahead to where I've already gone from annoying and inappropriate to charming and endearing.  WHITE 10-23-09 56.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: You're a married man and I won't be involved with you in any way.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I know, I'm sorry. Why don't we talk about it over lunch. I could be there tomorrow--

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Are you listening to me?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Every word.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Really? Well, words matter. Actions matter. They have consequences. If you want people to take you seriously, then act accordingly. Do you understand me, Barney?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: What am I saying?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (beat) "Be great in act, as you have in thought".

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: (surprised) Well, yes, exactly. (curt) I have to go. Stop this nonsense and focus on your marriage.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm so happy you called. Thank you. Barney smiles, feeling like progress is being made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nouveau riche house in a nouveau riche neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The furnishings of their home are excessive and overbeari There's no doubting it's The Second Mrs. P who decorated  WHITE 10-23-09 57.
