SHOPPING BAGS from high end department stores stretch alo the entire length of the ground floor hallway. With the phone tucked to her ear, The Second Mrs. P flutt about, rearranging knick-knacks.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: (into phone) --I had a bowl of cottage cheese and fruit, I'm watching my figure... Ma, so don't eat bagels if they make you bloated... No, you have a wonderful figure for a woman your age.... what did I say wrong?... Well it's the only voice I have so if you don't like it we can start sending each other telegrams instead... She's flipping through a stack of framed wall hangings le against a wall, deciding on something to hang. She pulls the familiar sketch CLARA made of Barney drawn to look li Satan. It makes her gag. She carries it into the kitchen-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Barney is reading the sport section with breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: (re: Clara's Drawing) Get rid of this filth... No, ma, I wasn't talking to you... To the king of Macedonia, who do you think?... Listen, I have to go, I still have to vacuum the Broadloom downstairs... I had to fire the maid... Why? Because when Barney and I would go out his father would sneak over and have sex with her... I know it's disgusting... Ma, you asked!... Okay, I'll pick you up at noon. Goodbye. She hangs up. Looks at Clara's drawing again.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you don't throw this out, I will.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'll bring it up to the country house.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: And make sure your buddy doesn't throw up all over the place. We just changed all the carpets. Barney continues reading - tuning her out completely.  WHITE 10-23-09 58.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Barney!

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Tell me something - you were at the game last night, do you think the score somehow changed overnight?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (standing) I have to get going.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What's important?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: THIS. Talking. Communicating. This is what marriage is.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (annoyed) You don't want Boogie puking all over the carpets and your mother's bloated. Does that pretty much cover it?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Do I talk down to you like that?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I really have to go. See you ina couple days. A quick peck on the forehead and he's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney waits in his car outside a fleabag hotel. Boogie emerges from the building, high, stumbles toward Barney's car. He looks like the full-fledged junkie he has become. His appearance is shocking to Barney.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Guess I don't qualify for the "you look great" greeting.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Just get in. Boogie gets in the car. In bad shape.  WHITE 10-23-09 59.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought you came here to kick.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: C'mon, I was on a fifteen hour flight I had to fix one more time. (beat) I'm really going to kick this time. A week locked up in the country and I'll be good as new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney pulls up to the cottage with Boogie passed out in front seat. THE SECOND MRS. P is on the porch, drinking wine, looking very attractive in a tight fitting summer d Barney helps Boogie up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: I thought I'd surprise you.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney drops Boogie onto the bed. He's out cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner is already laid out. A roast, potatoes, greens.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me this was why you were coming up here?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: He asked me not to tell anyone, and he needed somewhere safe to kick.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's called rehab Barney goes to the bar and fixes himself a drink

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Do you want one?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Just bring the bottle to the table so you don't have to jump up every two minutes.  WHITE 10-23-09 60.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Wow, are we ever in for a good time this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: You don't know the half of it. Look what I found while going through your pockets. She produces a BILL from 'GRAND FLORISTS'

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Well played, no hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You're going to be very embarrassed when those show up.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Stop. I called the florist. While usually discreet about their clients, the ray of sunshine that is you left the manager eager to tell me you have a standing order of roses to someone in New York every week.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. This is ridiculous. You want to pick through every receipt I have? I'm not going to stay here and take this. Barney storms out to the DECK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She follows him out.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Be a man, Barney. Barney stares out at the lake. He won't look her in the e

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I've never been unfaithful to you.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: So who are the flowers for?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: An actress we're trying to get for a new pilot.  WHITE 10-23-09 61.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Can we talk about this in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: No. I don't understand what you want anymore. Before we got married you couldn't keep your hands off me. Now it's been months since we made love. You say you've never been unfaithful, so what is it then? (softer) On our wedding night I came up behind you and you were saying how hopelessly in love you were. It was the happiest moment of my life. I keep going back to that just to have something to hold onto. (beat) What happened? Why did you even marry me? He can't bring himself to answer her. It hurts her like hell, but she's not going to cry in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P_, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm so ashamed. And you are such a liar. Fuck you. She goes back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of cicada. The calm of the lake. Barney's cotta is a true country paradise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wiping the sleep from her eyes, The Second Mrs. P shuffle into the kitchen and finds a note on the fridge: "Had to go into town for the day. Call you later - Barney

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Shmuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney parks in front of Grumpy's and heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Scotches on the table. Izzy reads the paper as he wai for Barney in a booth. Barney drops down across from him.  WHITE 10-23-09 62. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I have to get a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. (beat) Did you cheat?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Did she?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: So what happened?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm in love with someone else.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You don't know her.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Where'd you meet her?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You don't want to know.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: You ask me here to talk and now you don't want to talk. What do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Some paternal wisdom.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Boychick, listen. I know how hard marriage can be. In the beginning it's all briskets and blowjobs and la-di-da, ain't life grand, and then real life starts. You come home from work and all they want to do is talk and all you want to do is screw and soon enough every (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: day is like pushing an avocado through a cheese grater - it all just feels like you're holding shit in your hands.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Maybe you just need to take a step back before you do anything rash. Let's take a good, hard look at the situation. You're married to a well- bred woman who's loaded, makes a nice, flaky kugel and has a great rack. Many successful marriages were built on far less.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Can we drop this? Just forget I ever said anything.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: She's a tough cookie. If you divorce her, she's gonna take you to the cleaners.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You know how rich her father is. She's going to inherit a shitload of money.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: And you think that'll stop her from taking all of yours?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Izzy registers the depth of Barney's true feelings.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: So tell me her name.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Miriam.  WHITE 10-23-09 64.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: And is this the one? Is she the mother of your children?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Alright then, let's do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney lays on the sofa watching TV. Scotch. Cigar

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (into phone) I'll be back tomorrow. I'm too drunk to drive tonight.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're leaving me with the junkie?! Are you with your whore?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So you do have a whore! You sonofabitch, my father was right about you-- Barney holds the phone away from his ear as she drones on He considers responding, but then just hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. BARNEY'S CAR
dialogues.text: Still hungover, chugging coffee, Barney drives up to the cottage. The RADIO NEWS tells us it's 8:25 AM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney enters the house. Walks down the hall. Hears noise coming from the guest bedroom. He opens the door to find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Second Mrs. P, naked, moaning, and riding Boogie in t midst of hot, hard sex until she sees Barney:

dialogues.speaker: AAAAAAA
dialogues.text: The Second Mrs. P rolls off Boogie and falls onto the flo with a cringe worthy THUD.  WHITE 10-23-09 65. Kicking and screaming, she scrambles to cover herself wit the bedding, spilling an open bottle of Whisky in the pro Barney is frozen with shock

dialogues.speaker: GET OUT
dialogues.text: Barney backs out of the room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes a moment for the situation to sink in. Once it does, he smiles. Things are looking up for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In only her nightie, The Second Mrs. P storms out of the guest room past Barney.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: This is all your fault, you bastard, sonofabitch- -

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: My fault?! Barney follows her into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In tears, she throws on whatever clothes she can find.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: My wife and my best friend...

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: I brought him something to eat, he was trembling, his sheets were soaked, I only laid down beside him to try to keep him warm... I still don't know how he got my nightie off.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: It must have been magic, then.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: We shouldn't talk about this now while I'm so upset.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You're so upset?! She hustles out and down the hall. He follows.  WHITE 10-23-09 66.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: I'm going to my mother's.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Tell her we're getting divorced! She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes toward her car. Barney right behind her

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: You tell her yourself! No, don't - she has a root canal today. She gets in her car, starts the engine, rolls down the wi

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I was coming back to try to work things out.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Bullshit. I bet the two of you perverts arranged this together

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Ha! I'm going to kill him for this then I'll come for you, and just for kicks, your mother after that!

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MRS. P
dialogues.text: Go to hell! Animal! She drives away, kicking up a cloud of dust in her wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney walks in to find Boogie chugging right from a bott of Scotch. He's already very drunk.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I should kill you for this.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: What you should have done was call first. Boogie pours Barney a glass, who reticently takes it.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: How could you do that to me?  WHITE 10-23-09 67.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: She did it to me. It was innocent enough to start with - she brought me something to eat, started talking - you know how that goes - tells me how you've been shirking your husbandly duties, que sera sera...

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: So you fucked her?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: It was the only thing that would shut her up. Boogie shakes the empty Scotch bottle at Barney.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Check the dining room. I'm going to need you to do something for me. Testify that I came home to you in bed with my wife.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: You sly bastard - you planned this all along.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Who could plan this?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don't see any Scotch, but look here... Boogie comes back up with an open WOOD BOX containing the GUN from Izzy. He takes it out, waves it around.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you say? Duel at high noon? But I don't think we have enough booze to get us there. Barney grabs the gun away from Boogie.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: That's loaded, shmuck. There's more Scotch in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ice is dropped into two tumblers. More Scotch poured. They've gone through half the bottle and are visibly drun Boogie peruses Barney's book collection. He picks up Clar sketch that's leaning against the wall.  WHITE 10-23-09 68.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Did you hear they named a new auditorium at Barnard after her? Crazy Clara Chambers - she wasn't too bad a poet, actually. I bet this is worth a pretty penny now. Hey, who gets the residuals from her books?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I signed the rights over to charity right after she died. Listen, will you testify or not?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You know what? It's time you came through for me for once.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: How many times have I bailed you out over the years?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: I wasn't counting.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Neither was I.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: You sure about that?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: When I had nothing, I borrowed for you. You owe me.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Well isn't this getting interesting. But I'd like to go for a swim and think it over. You must have a snorkel and flippers here. Boogie grabs the bottle of Scotch and heads to the sunroo Barney follows him out, the gun still in his sweater pock

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boogie rifles through a trunk and finally comes up with a SNORKEL, MASK AND FLIPPERS.  WHITE 10-23-09 69.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: How's your novel coming along?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Are you asking as a friend or an investor?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Both.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: I'm still working on it.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You're a fraud.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Oh, have I let poor Barney down?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you have.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Too fucking bad. You know what, man? I brought you in. I educated you. I put the right books in your hands, and look what you've become. A TV hustler, married to a rich man's vulgar daughter.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Not so vulgar that you wouldn't bang her.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: And she wasn't the only wife of yours I had. Next time I'm in New York I'll call on your tart and make it a trifecta. Boogie pushes through the screen door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boogie staggers toward the dock, drunk and barely able to walk a straight line.

dialogues.speaker: FUCK YOU.
dialogues.text: Barney CHARGES Boogie. They start to wrestle but are too drunk to really take it anywhere serious. They break apar winded and woozy.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What happened to you?  WHITE 10-23-09 70.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Absolutely nothing happened to me; and that's what you take as a personal offense. I am not your pet project. Not your vicarious life. Not your hope.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Not my friend? Boogie doesn't even think to answer. He just swigs from t bottle again.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you realize you haven't come close to giving me an apology?

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: Let me recommend another book to stock your shelf with; "The Life of Heinrich Heine", who upon his death bed was begged by his loved ones to ask for God's forgiveness before he passed. But good old Heinrich had only this to say: "God will surely forgive me - after all, that's his fucking job".

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Don't count on it.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: I'm going for a swim. Boogie slips on the flippers, waddles onto the dock

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Boogie, stop! You're too drunk and you can barely swim anyway. I'll shoot, you prick, I will! Barney fires a WARNING SHOT straight up into the air.

dialogues.speaker: BOOGIE
dialogues.text: There you go! But this time shoot it at me you fucking coward! See for yourself what's really inside this mossy, dampened cavity you think is a heart. C'mon, do it! Barney stares him down. A silent rage boiling inside. Boo grins, snaps on the goggles and the snorkel, spreads his arms wide, tilts his head back...  WHITE 10-23-09 71.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Don't you fucking move. Barney drunkenly staggers forward, pointing the gun at Bo AND THIS ALL HAPPENS IN HAZY FLASH: Barney TRIPS -- the g FIRES -- Boogie lets himself FALL backward into the lake. It appears the gun fired into the air, but he could have fired in Boogie's direction. We can't be sure. Barney turns and heads back up into the house. We DO NOT see Boogie resurface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney stumbles in. Barney hits the bottle hard - one shot after another.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The bottle now empty. Barney's passed out on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: EVEN LATER
dialogues.text: Barney on the floor, woken by the the RUMBLING of a TWIN AIRPLANE, starting from a distance and approaching fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stumbles out to the porch, still half drunk. The PLANE flying over a distant hillside.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNIFORMED POLICEMEN and SEARCH DOGS scour the property ar Barney's house. DIVERS break the surface of the lake's wa A POLICE BOAT out there too. Barney watches all this from the dock.

dialogues.speaker: O'HEARNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Busy day. There's a big fire a few miles east.  WHITE 10-23-09 72. DETECTIVE SEAN O'HEARNE, younger, slimmer, healthier than know him to be, steps up along side Barney.

dialogues.speaker: O'HEARNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Twenty cottages burned so far

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: They're wasting their time out there. I told them I looked all over the lake in my boat. He's broken into a cottage, emptied it of all the booze and pills he could find and moved on.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: But he leaves his clothes and wallet here?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: He took someone else's clothes.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: No break-ins have been reported. Got something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney opens the refrigerator and passes O'Hearne a cold O'Hearne saunters through the house, sipping the beer He stops at the FRAMED SKETCH BY CLARA leaning against th

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: That's kind of sick.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: My first wife made that.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: (taking out notepad) Oh yeah? What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: She's dead.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: Did you catch her fucking someone too?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: She killed herself.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: Beat you to it, I guess.  WHITE 10-23-09 73.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What the fuck does that mean? I called you guys.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, you did. So why didn't you mention this gun? O'Hearne pulls out Barney's GUN, in a plastic evidence ba

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: My dad is a retired cop. He gave it to me for protection.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: (dawning) Are you fuckin' Izzy Panofsky's kid?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: No shit. So why are there two rounds missing?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Boogie and I were horsing around.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: By shooting off rounds?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: We were drunk.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: This was after you caught him fucking your wife?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: It wasn't like that.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: You shot off the rounds before you walked in on them screwing?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: After.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yes.  WHITE 10-23-09 74.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: So you did shoot him.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah, right through his fucking heart, Jesus Christ--

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: (take notes) Now we're getting somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Are you a complete idiot? Why are you wasting your time here? Go find him! Have you thought that he might be hurt somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: And what about this piece of ass you're keeping in New York - the florist gave us her name - Miriam Grant... Barney grabs O'Hearne --

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You keep her out of this-- O'Hearne drives a knee into his groin, then lays one into Barney's face, sending him to the floor

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: Two bullets shot from your gun just after you caught your best friend banging your wife. You threatened to kill them both, and now he's missing. Unless you ate him, we'll find the body before sundown. So tell me where the body is and I'll say you were cooperative and remorseful, you'll get yourself a smart Jew lawyer and be out in no time. No one cares about a useless junkie anyway. Barney lifts himself to one knee.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Go to hell. O'Hearne kicks him in the gut once, then again, when... IZZY grabs O'Hearne from behind and throws him off Barney

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: What are you doin' here, Panofsky?  WHITE 10-23-09 75.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I got a call from my son.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: Very sweet, but he attacked an officer of the law.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: From where I'm standing this looks like police brutality.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: Like you're one to talk.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: You leave your hands off him.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: He's goin' down for murder.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Really? It seems those razor-sharp detective skills of yours missed one tiny detail; you don't have a body. Now you got anything else to say, talk to his lawyer. O'Hearne exits. Izzy kneels to look at Barney's face.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Dad! Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Alright, alright. Let me get you some ice.

dialogues.speaker: TV_SCREEN IN THE GREEN ROOM
dialogues.text: O'Hearne is on TV responding to a crowd of reporters out the Townships.

dialogues.speaker: O' HEARNE
dialogues.text: --For the moment no charges are being laid. We've searched the area for three weeks. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: O'HEARNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No body has been found yet, so this will remain a missing persons case even with the overwhelming circumstantial evidence implicating Mr. Panofsky. Our hands are tied. PULL OUT from the TV and follow the RECEPTIONIST, carryin YELLOW ENVELOPE onto the soundstage. Barney is half-aslee as the crew sets up for the next shot.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Barney, the papers you were waiting for just arrived-- Barney bolts upright, grabs the envelope, tears it open a pulls out his divorce papers. He rushes to the nearest ph dials, and signs the marked pages.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Miriam Grant please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam sitting at her desk. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Miriam, I'm divorced.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Barney- -

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm going to be in New York tomorrow. How about dinner?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Lunch?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Please, Miriam.  WHITE 10-23-09 77. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Is the ink even dry yet?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Let me check. Miriam chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's only lunch. Just once. If you decide you don't ever want to see me again, well, that's it.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Honestly?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I swear. Long beat. Waiting... Waiting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flying over Manhattan. A sunny morning in the big apple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney pulls up to the hotel in a cab and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two pair of shoes, three suits, four ties laid on the bed The clock reads: 10:03 AM. Barney is sitting at the desk his hotel suite, scribbling on hotel stationary: "Conversations Topics: All The President's Men, Herzog, Alphonse Daudet..." Barney drops his pen. This is idiotic He starts pacing. Then dials the concierge.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (into phone) I'd like a bottle of Dom Perignon well chilled, and a dozen long stem roses brought to my room at exactly two o'clock.... make that two bottles and two dozen roses.... great. CU - He UNLOCKS the MINI BAR. Grabs TWO Mini Scotches. Pours them over ice.  WHITE 10-23-09 78. He does the same again - and again - and again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The swanky hotel restaurant is filled with the lunch crow Barney's seated at a table. He's dressed to the nine's bu sweaty, clammy, drunk. He rattles the ice in his empty tumbler at a passing waiter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney splashes his face with water, pats himself dry. Lo at himself in the mirror. Takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the bathroom, he walks a short corridor back into th restaurant. Just as he turns the corner he CUTS BACK and hides, pressing himself against the wall and spying on--

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Being led to their table. She's a heart stopping vision. Even more gorgeous than the first time he laid eyes on he

dialogues.speaker: AT THEIR TABLE
dialogues.text: Barney drops into his seat across from Miriam, startling

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Hi. Barney doesn't look so good. Sweaty, pale, nervous as hel

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm so happy you made it.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Yes, well--

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Have you eaten? Is it hot in here?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: No, and no.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Great. Champagne? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is an occasion, we should have champagne, don't you think? (grabbing waiter) A bottle of Dom Perignon. (to Miriam) Did you want to order now?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I haven't looked at the menu yet.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Of course, take your time. (to waiter) Just the Champagne. And some Beluga. The Iranian stuff, the Russian is too salty... (to Miriam) It is hot in here... Barney opens his collar. Perspiration forming on his brow

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm great. There's so much I want to talk about... Oh, I know - have you read, uh, what's it called... give me a second--

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Barney, hold on. I want to be clear on something. I hope you didn't get divorced on my account.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Of course I did.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: You hardly know me. The waiter arrives with the Champagne.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Wonderful, now we can celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Celebrate what? The room begins to tilt and sway. Barney's panicking, desperately trying to hold it together.  WHITE 10-23-09 80.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (slurring words) Now that I'm no longer a married man we can... we're finally here together... you, me...

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Barney, are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Excuse me. He BOLTS toward the MEN'S ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney is throwing up into the toilet of his suite. Miria pulls the bathroom door shut. Then, there's a KNOCKING at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Room service.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Miriam is sitting in an easy chair, her legs crossed, rea the New York Times. Barney stirs awake. She moves to sit at the edge of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You're never going to speak to me again I'm going to kill myself. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Are you done?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Please don't leave. She reaches for his page of HANDWRITTEN CRIB NOTES titled "conversation topics".  WHITE 10-23-09 81.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: What would you like to talk about - All The President's Men, Herzog or Alphonse Daudet - nice reference, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Don't be so modest. You obviously expected me to come up to your room.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: So the champagne and roses are for another woman? Barney lifts his throbbing head to see for himself. Sure enough there's two bottles of champagne and two dozen ros

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Oh God... He covers his face and begins to MOAN. Miriam finds it al utterly amusing. She pries his hands from his face.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Why don't you get cleaned up, we'll get some fresh air, and maybe a slice of pizza. I'm absolutely starving. Off Barney's delight --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stroll along the park. Barney rambles on, desperatel trying to keep Miriam engaged. He hardly even breathes between words.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: --"The Big Apple" is actually an old racetrack term, credited to John Fitzgerald - a sports writer for the herald in the 30's. He'd heard old stable hands from Mississippi use it when referring to the New York racetracks. Getting to race in New York was considered hitting the big time - getting a bite of that "Big Apple" and I'm just going to keep talking because I'm afraid if I stop (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: there's going to be pause, or a break where you'll say "it's getting late" or, "I should probably get going" and I'm not ready for that to happen, I don't want it to happen. Ever. And then he finally just runs out of steam. They stop wal and face each other for what seems like an eternity to hi

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: There it was. The pause.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I'm still here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk along the East River. Their body language now more intimate.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: --I adored my father. He was my hero. Until I found out he was sleeping with every factory girl he could get on the side. (beat) It killed my mother. That's what gave her cancer.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: That's a bit unfair.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: No, it's not. It devastated every part of her. Mind and body. Heart and soul. And that will never happen to me.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I would never do that to you.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I want one thing from you.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Anything.  WHITE 10-23-09 83.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: See, that's what scares me about you. Don't answer ‘anything’. That's not real, and life is real. It's made up of little things - minutes and hours and errands and naps and routine, and that has to be enough. After all you've done to pursue me, how can I ever trust you?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: That's a reasonable question. Barney thinks hard. He knows he needs to come up with something good. Then he rifles through his pocket and pul out a CIGAR CLIPPER. He SNAPS it shut for effect.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll cut it off. Right away.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Now you're offering to be my eunuch?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Like I said, I'll do anything for you, Miriam.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Well, you're not going to do that. We're going to be needing it. She kisses him. Together they fall into an embrace neithe will ever forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney and Miriam have an outdoor wedding ceremony at his cottage. Only closest friends and family are in attendanc including Solange and Jeff (from the wedding) and his boy

dialogues.speaker: NOTARY
dialogues.text: --And do you take this man to be your lawfully wedded husband?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: NOTARY
dialogues.text: And do you--

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I sure as hell do.  WHITE 10-23-09 84. Barney can't wait another second. He kisses her

dialogues.speaker: MAZEL TOV
dialogues.text: Izzy, tears already streaming down his face, grabs Miriam and gives her a hard kiss on the lips. Everyone CHEERS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party is winding down. Guests are still up at the hou on the porch, drinking, slow dancing. It's a beautiful ni Barney is out on the dock alone, staring at the lake when joins him. She wraps her arms around him from behind.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: He promised he'd never miss any of my weddings. Miriam kisses him tenderly then takes him by the hand and leads him back up to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney and Miriam's apartment. (Where Barney still lives)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney is chopping an ONION as he prepares lunch. His eye filled with tears. Miriam walks in carrying MICHAEL, who only a few months old.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Oh, Barney, put it in the freezer.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Put the onion in the freezer for a few minutes before you chop it. Then it won't make you cry.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: How did I not know that?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I think he's ready for his nap.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Really?  WHITE 10-23-09 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They watch Michael fast asleep in his crib. Then look at each other with mischievous grins --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney appears in the doorway in his boxers. Miriam is already naked and waiting with her best "come hither" loo He runs and leaps onto the bed. They laugh hysterically a they roll around and start to make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A perfect day. Barney and Izzy sit on the deck, their fee up, drinking Scotch, smoking cigars. Michael (12) and Kate (9) play frisbee by the lake with M The sun is setting. The sky a perfect orange hue. Barney looks out at the stunning landscape, his children and his gorgeous wife. He closes his eyes, takes a deep breath, holding onto thi moment of perfection. He opens his eyes. Izzy's watching him. Barney expects a typical Izzy-ism.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: You did good, kid. Izzy puffs away on his cigar, leaving it at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney and Michael (13) are fishing in a small outboard m boat in the middle of the lake. Michael is bored silly as any young boy would be.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Anything?  WHITE 10-23-09 86.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: A nibble?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No, dad.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Burgers?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Tell your mother we threw them all back. Barney lays down their rods and pulls on the RIPCORD. The engine won't turn. He tries again, and again, working up big sweat. He takes a breather. Michael stares blankly at him.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'll get it. Again - harder, angrier.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Need any help? PADDLING toward them in a canoe - BLAIR (52). Tree hugger Birkenstocks. Soft. Harmless.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (yanking on rope) No - thanks - it - just needs a little-- He TEARS the rope right out of the motor.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: Just toss me your anchor rope and I'll tow you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam hands Blair a glass of Iced Tea.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: I'm renting a cottage here. I just moved from New York.  WHITE 10-23-09 87.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What do you do, Blair?

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: I work in radio.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I used to work in radio in New York.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: Really? Where?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: At WZAJ. It's a little jazz station.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: Sure I know it. Ronald Lewis is an old friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: You're kidding? He gave me my first job.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: Isn't that coincidence. The universe works in strange and mysterious ways.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I was going to throw some burgers on the bar-b-que. Want to join us?

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: I'm a vegan, but thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: A what? Is that treatable?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I could make a salad.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: I don't want to impose, and I should paddle back before it gets dark. It was lovely to meet the both of you. They all say goodbye and Blair exits.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (calling out) Michael, want to do the bar-b-que?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah.  WHITE 10-23-09 88.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Fire it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar-b-que is lit. Miriam carries hamburger patties ou to the boys when they all hear -- RRRRR - the sound of an outboard motor. They all look dow to the lake where they see Blair standing on the dock.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: (yelling) It was just a loose distributor wire. And I re-attached the rip cord. Blair waves, then hops in his canoe.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: That was nice of him. Barney grunts and waves half heartedly.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO PRESENT DAY.
dialogues.text: Miriam's RADIO SHOW plays on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --and we're going to end our program with a request from our regular listener, Alphonse from Montreal: Leonard Cohen's "Dance Me To The End Of Love". I'm Miriam Grant. As always, thank you for listening.

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: As he chops an ONION while cooking dinner. The phone RING He answers, pressing his sleeve to his eyes to halt the s

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Hello?... Michael, hi... I land at five... I'll just grab a cab to your place... okay, love you. He hangs up. The song continues over --  WHITE 10-23-09 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney riding in a yellow cab with a bag from SCHWARTZ'S the seat beside him. He sees a young couple kissing in th same spot where he and Miriam first kissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney and Michael watch a hockey game together. Barney i yelling at the TV, halfway through a bottle of Scotch and smoking a cigar. The table littered with remnants of a me from Schwartz's Smoked Meat.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (yelling at TV) Useless goddamn pansy ref, get your head out of your ass!! Caroline enters - business suit, briefcase. A belligerent Barney coupled the disorderly mess of the apartment is th last thing she wanted to end her day with. Michael greets her at the door.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: I thought you were going out for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (apologetic) ) Dad brought in smoked meat from Montreal.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: (to Michael) Didn't we agree to no cigars in the house? Barney looks to Michael for backup, but is met with silen He grudgingly taps out the cigar.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Am I still allowed to use the bathroom or would you prefer I leave my business in paper bags by the door? Recyclable ones, of course.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINE
dialogues.text: Turn that down please, I have to get up early. She heads off to the bedroom. Michael scowls at Barney.  WHITE 10-23-09 90.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What? The woman hates me.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Maybe she wouldn't hate you if you didn't behave like a child.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Chicken and the egg.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No, dad, it's not. You can't keep acting this way. Not with us, or Mom and Blair.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: So you're speaking for your mother now?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Just leave them alone already. She's not coming back to you.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: If that's what you're so angry about, then fine. Tell your mother from this moment on she is forgotten. Erased. Nothing but a wisp of gray on the otherwise full, dark mane of my life.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I'm sure she'll appreciate the sentiment if not the poetry. Good-night. Michael starts to walk out--

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Michael...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What have you told her about me?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I tell her everything. That's what couples do.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Spare me the sermon. I see the way she looks at me.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  WHITE 10-23-09 91.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I saw O'Hearne's book on her night table. She can't even be bothered to hide it from me. How could you let her read that? She even has all these pages dog-eared in it... (beat) When she asks about Boogie, what do you tell her? Michael doesn't answer Barney readies himself for one of the hardest things he's ever had to ask.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you think I could have possibly done that? Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Only you really know. Michael exits. That devastates Barney. He simply deflates From outside, a CAR ALARM has begun to whine. Its incessa squeal turns into --

dialogues.speaker: A KETTLE WHISTLING.
dialogues.text: Barney pours two cups of tea. Then smells a jar of HONEY, not sure if it's still good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney carries the tea and honey on a tray. Miriam is on the sofa watching a NEWS MAGAZINE PROGRAM.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: (re: on TV) That's Taylor Gates.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (re: honey) Tell me if this is still good.  WHITE 10-23-09 92.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: She was my intern before we got married. She could barely string two words together. Miriam drips the honey into her tea without smelling it. passes it to Barney who is still not convinced it's edibl

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Honey doesn't go bad.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Ever?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Archeologists found honey in Egyptian tombs thousands of years old and it was still edible. Barney shrugs, uses the honey. Miriam curls herself into the corner of the sofa, feeling depressed.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone seems to be doing pretty interesting things nowadays.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Giving birth and raising two amazing children is pretty interesting.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: But it doesn't command much respect now does it?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Miriam- -

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter. Miriam grabs a magazine from the coffee table, shutting d the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn. Michael (now 18) and a few buddies have loaded th last of his things into a small U-Haul. It's off to colle

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: (crying) My baby.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Mom, I'm not going to war. I'll be back for thanksgiving.  WHITE 10-23-09 93. She kisses Michael one last time.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm going inside.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (to Barney) Any last words of wisdom?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You need money, ask me. Don't start selling dope.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: No selling dope. Got it. Anything else? Barney takes him in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I love you too, dad. A quick goodbye to Kate (16).

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself. Michael jumps into the truck, starts to pull out.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Pull over if you get tired!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney and Miriam having lunch out in the lush, beautiful garden of the Ritz. Miriam stares absently at her plate. Her mind elsewhere. She sets down her cutlery. Her food only half eaten.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: He had to move out eventually.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I know. That's not it. (beat) I want to go back to work. I've been thinking about this for a while. Blair said he can get me freelance work. It's just research and writing for now but it could lead to other things. Maybe even on air.  WHITE 10-23-09 94.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: And I'm sure Blair will do everything he can for you.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Stop that.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (beat) Are you unhappy?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: No. Not in the way you're trying to get at.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Then in which way? JEAN THE MAITRE'D comes over.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: How is everything?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Excellent, as always.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: May I get you anything else?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: We're fine. Thank you, Jean. Jean leaves. Barney sulks, polishing off his wine.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I knew how you would take this.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: It's just that I've worked this hard so you wouldn't ever have to. So you could be here with the kids and me. We both agreed that was important.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: It was important. But Michael's gone, soon Kate will be too, and you're as grown up as you'll ever be. Where does that leave me? I need more stimulation in my life. I have to believe I can be something other than just a wife and mother.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'll quit working. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll retire early, travel, go to Italy, get a Villa on Lake Como.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: You can't just fix this like you do everything else. I don't want you to. (beat) I need to do this. Can you try and understand?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Of course. Whatever you want to do, I'm behind it. A hundred percent. He fakes through the deep panic he's feeling inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam interviews a distinguished looking man on the air

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: ...Well, Mr. Dalhousie, that's all the time we have. Thank you so much for coming in.

dialogues.speaker: GUEST
dialogues.text: It is was a pleasure. Thank you. The ON AIR light turns OFF. Miriam lets out a big sigh of relief. The staff on the other side of the glass APPLAUD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam walks down the Hall with BLAIR.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I hope that wasn't too painful.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? It was fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Stop it, Blair.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: Really, Miriam, you're a natural.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Thank you. Would you excuse me, I'm going to call Barney.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: Of course.  WHITE 10-23-09 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone RINGS through an empty house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney is sitting at the bar, watching the hockey game. T bar ERUPTS at a bad penalty call.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What the hell kind of call is that INSERT - BARNEY'S CELL PHONE - on the bar, ringing. He doesn't hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam hangs up. Upset that Barney didn't answer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney tiptoes into the dark, quiet apartment. He's drunk and trying very hard to be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam is already asleep. Barney is about to crawl into b

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Where have you been? Miriam turns on the bedside lamp.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I was at Grumpy's watching the game.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Did you hear my interview?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I just lost track of--

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: This was important to me. You knew that right?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (beat) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: But you missed my first on air interview because you were drunk and watching a hockey game, like you've done a thousand times before.  WHITE 10-23-09 97.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (beat) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Okay. I wanted to be sure we're clear on what happened here tonight. Miriam flips back over and turns the lamp OFF.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Should I sleep on the sofa? She turns the lamp back ON.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Stop feeling sorry for yourself. You're not sleeping on the sofa, we don't sleep apart. Good night. She turns the light OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney has accompanied IZZY to his Mother's grave.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: You got yourself a plot yet?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: You should get one. The good ones go fast. Izzy places a rock on the double headstone: ESTHER PANOFSKY - 1925 - 1972, Wife to Izzy, Mother to Ba Engraved beside hers is Izzy's name: ISRAEL PANOFSKY

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Sure. But he's not very convincing.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I was thinking, why don't you move in with us? Now that the kids are gone we have more than enough space.  WHITE 10-23-09 98.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: Thanks, but no thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I don't like the thought of you being alone.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I'm not alone. See that? That's alone. Izzy points to a single grave beside theirs.

dialogues.speaker: IZZY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Buried alone. No wife. No kids. That's alone. I'm going to be right here with your mother. When you get to my age you'll see what a comfort that is.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I know it must be hard without her

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: I'm used to being without her. I need to get laid.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (walking away) Jesus Christ...

dialogues.speaker: IZZY
dialogues.text: What? How long have you ever had to hold out, Mr. THREE wives!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of Miriam's friends including BLAIR, are over for dinner. Blair holds court while Barney broods over his Sc bored and annoyed with Blair's politically correct discou

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: --I think it's fair to say that in 50 years we'll look back on this time and our inhumane treatment of animals for the sake of mass consumption, as a shameful and barbaric chapter in our history, much like how we perceive segregation or McCarthyism- - Barney can't stand another second of this. He gets up and brings a cigar back to the table.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Barney, please don't smoke that. You know it irritates Blair's asthma.  WHITE 10-23-09 99. Without a moment's pause, Barney heads out to the den.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney lights his cigar with great pleasure. The dinner guests continue with their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney crawls into bed with a moan. Miriam's reading. Bar stares at the ceiling, exhausted. Long silence. Miriam sets down her book.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: If you can't at least be civil with my friends then don't bother joining us.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I thought I was perfectly civil.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: You fell asleep at the table. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I forgot to ask, how was the cemetery?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Good times. The phone RINGS. Barney groans. Reaches for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A non-descript building with a red neon sign: MASSAGE. Ba parks right in front, then enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUSH IN through a beaded curtain and into the waiting roo of an old school "rub and tug" massage parlor. The Madame, GOLDIE (45) is consoling a working girl, who sobbing. Goldie looks up at CAMERA --

dialogues.speaker: GOLDIE
dialogues.text: Barney...? Barney nods. She takes his hand. Barney's eyes searching. He's at a loss. She takes him by the arm and leads him do the hall.  WHITE 10-23-09 100.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After they finished, the girl left the room to get a hot towel. When she went back in... At least he went happy. She stops in front of room #4.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He talked about you all the time. You made him so proud. She opens a door and lets Barney go in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney enters, takes in the room. Goldie shuts the door leaving him alone. The lighting dim. The walls bare. A sh with a bottle of baby oil, a box of kleenex. Izzy's body lays on the table, covered in a white sheet. peaceful, half-grin on his face. Barney sits on a small chair beside the body. He lifts th edge of the sheet and takes his father's hand in his. He starts to laugh at the situation, patting his father's ha Then he squeezes it tighter, holding it with both his han pressing it to his forehead, and starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney exits the room. He sits beside Goldie in the reception. They share a quiet moment.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDIE
dialogues.text: He didn't get a chance to settle up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Barney reaches into his pocket, hands her a couple hundred from his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney grabs an ice cube from the freezer for his Scotch. Before shutting the door he pulls out an ONION - stares a it quizzically - then puts it back.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You sure you don't want anything?

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, thanks.  WHITE 10-23-09 101. Barney goes into the DEN and refills his Scotch before si down to continue his Scrabble game with Kate.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's your turn.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Right there. Barney stares at the board. Confused.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Sorry. He sets down his pieces.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What word is that? INSERT - SCRABBLE BOARD. His pieces spell: "ATTNY"

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Attorney.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You're missing half the letters.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: It's the abbreviation.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: When you get that lazy with cheating, I know you're tired. She gets up and starts to clean up.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Leave that, I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: No, dad. Let me. Barney can tell that she needs to keep herself busy. He takes her arm to stop her and pull her down to sit.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Do you want to talk about it?  WHITE 10-23-09 102.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I'll be fine. I'm just happy it only took eight months to realize he was a jerk. He pulls her into a comforting embrace. That's all it tak for her to start crying in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: It'll be okay. I promise. She cries as long as she needs to. They break apart, she wipes her eyes on her sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me get you a tissue.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: No, I'll get it. She gets up to go to the washroom. Barney watches her go. His eyes drift over and stop on LEO'S PAINTING prominentl displayed on the wall. It's an abstract multi-colored whirlpool that winds down to a black center. Barney's min follows it down to the black nothingness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam is interviewing Barney's old friend, LEO FASOLI (6 He's now a famous painter with an air of success and grav about him. Barney and Blair watch from the booth, along with Leo's f of the month, a stunning 28 year old BIMBO.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: --and we're back talking with renowned painter and artist, Leo Fasoli. Leo, you recently signed a seven figure deal with Simon and Schuster to publish your autobiography. But then you returned the money, saying you no longer wanted to do it. what happened?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: It proved to be more difficult than I originally thought it would be.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: In what way?  WHITE 10-23-09 103. Leo pauses.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Andre Gide, the French author, once said "nothing is as destructive to happiness as the remembrance of happiness lost".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney escorts Leo and his Bimbo out. A LIMO waits right outside the door. Leo lights a cigarette. For all his success, there's a sense of melancholy to him.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: (to Bimbo) A spetta un minuto, cara mia.

dialogues.speaker: BIMBO
dialogues.text: I love it when you speak Italian. She gives Leo a kiss, then slips into the limo.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: (re: Bimbo) You like this one? Leo just shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks again for doing the interview. It's a real coup for Miriam.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: It was my pleasure. She's an amazing woman.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Are you sure you can't stay the night? We'd love to have you over.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: There's nothing I would enjoy more but I have to get back to New York. They hug.

dialogues.speaker: LEO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've made a wonderful life for yourself. It makes me happy. Leo gets in the limo and is driven away.  WHITE 10-23-09 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blair has joined Barney and Miriam for dinner. Miriam and Blair enjoy lively conversation, while Barney broods in silence and polishes off another Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: Allow me a toast to you Barney. You really came through getting Leo to do the interview.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Yes you did. And a toast to Blair and his new job in New York

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: I don't have it yet.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Here's hoping. They drink. Miriam begins to clear the table.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: Let me help you.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Guests don't clean. Miriam heads to the kitchen. Long silence.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: So when are you going to find out?

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: Probably not for another month.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: A month? Jeez, don't be so soft. Push them. Let them know they'll lose you if they sit on their asses.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: I'm not one to be aggressive like that.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Just because you're gay, doesn't mean you can't be assertive.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: I'm not gay.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I didn't think so, but Miriam--  WHITE 10-23-09 105.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: Miriam thinks I'm gay?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I told her you weren't, but-- Miriam enters.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: So what you are boys talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam kisses Blair good-night.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming.

dialogues.speaker: BLAIR
dialogues.text: Thanks for another incredible meal, and again, congratulations, it was a fantastic interview.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Thanks. Blair exits. The moment the door closes she puts on her g face and marches into the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to confront Barney, who is just lighting up a cigar

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: What's with you? And don't say "what?". Let's just skip that whole part, okay?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I was giving him a few life lessons.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: By telling him I think he's gay? And who even jokes about that anymore?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I don't want to fight about Cher

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: We're not fighting about Blair. We're fighting about you.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Getting Leo to come in doesn't negate all the other interviews you've missed to get drunk and watch the game, or all the dinners you've ruined because you're incorrigible with my friends.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: It doesn't? Miriam is NOT amused.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I'm going to visit Michael for a week.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What? When?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Next weekend.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll take the week off.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: No. I think a little time apart will do us both good.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What? Where is this coming from?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: We've hardly been away from each other since we've been married. It'll be good for us to circulate the air in here a little. It's only a week - okay? Barney nods but he's not happy about this. Actually, he's scared to death. She gives him a kiss and exits.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. TAXI CAB
dialogues.text: BACK TO PRESENT DAY. Spring has arrived. Barney rides in a taxi. Coffee in hand. The cab stops at red light in front of the MONTREAL MUSEUM OF FINE ARTS. Barney looks out the window to see workers unraveling a DRAPERY announcing the next exposition:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE DRAPERY is a PHOTO OF LEO from back in his Rome da The thought of his departed friend hits him hard. The tax pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney enters the office in a foul mood. The RECEPTIONIST greets him with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Good morning, Barney.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: My car was stolen. Find out what I have to do to report it.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: It's parked in the lot. I have the keys right here. Barney grabs the keys, walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney slips into the soundstage just as they start rolli He's fidgety. Anxious.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SET
dialogues.text: A scene is playing out between O'Malley and the new, youn ditzy, SEXPOT (21), cast as the new Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: O'MALLEY
dialogues.text: I have a feeling you're going to work out just fine around here.

dialogues.speaker: SEXPOT
dialogues.text: Oh, I won't work out here. I go to the gym for that.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And CUT! Check the gate! Solange gets up from the DIRECTOR'S CHAIR. She's now directing the show, yet still dressed in the same type of revealing, tight outfit her character would have worn.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that everyone, completes the first episode of our 30th season! ! The whole crew bursts into applause.  WHITE 10-23-09 108. Even though it's Barney's show, the merriment around him seems to only make him more lonely and bitter. He ducks o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney's rifling through drawers and shelves looking for something. He's frustrated, angry. SOLANGE enters.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: Why did you leave the set? I thought you might want to give a speech.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Nope. Solange stands there grinning from ear to ear, eager to t him something. Barney continues his searching.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm not interested.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: You don't even know what I'm going to say.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in what you're going to say. That's the point.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: What if it were something really interesting? This is annoying the hell out of him.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Right now, I'm in a state of complete disinterest to all things. Is that clear or should I have someone translate? Solange drops an AIRPLANE TICKET in front of Barney.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: I'm going to Bulgaria. First Class. Barney looks at the ticket.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You haven't flown in thirty years. Barney hands her back the ticket and walks out of his off Solange follows...  WHITE 10-23-09 109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney goes to the coffee machine. One of those automatic ones where you press a button and it makes you a latte He makes his choice. The machine REVS and GRINDS, forcing them to raise their voices.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: I've been in systematic desensitization therapy to get over my fear of flying.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind? Some idiots keep printing thirty year old pictures of you in bikinis so old Bolsheviks can have something to jerk off to and you're going to fly half way around the world because of it? What do you imagine it will be like - that you'll step off the plane right onto the tarmac, Chanel glasses, Hermes scarf wrapped around your new 'do', a gaggle of paparazzi awaiting your arrival? You're a hundred and eighty years old Solange, get over it. The coffee machine stops. Dead silence. The entire office watching them. Solange fights back tears.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: What the hell is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: With me? My friend Leo just died! Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you hear me?!

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: (beat) Leo died a year ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (This is a replay of the OPENING OF THE MOVIE) Barney picks up the morning newspaper. Scans the front pa Something he reads upsets him.  WHITE 10-23-09 110.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: "LEO FASOLI, FAMED ITALIAN PAINTER, DIES AT 66."
dialogues.text: We now understand what Barney was reacting to originally. A SOCCER BALL rolls and stops at Barney's feet. JUSTIN (8) runs up and grabs the ball. He stares up at Barney. Barney stares back

dialogues.speaker: NEIGHBOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Justin, come on, we're late.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Hi Barney.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Good morning. Justin runs off. Barney turns back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney's reading the paper as he finishes his bagel and l Barney looks at his watch -- shit, he's late. Hops up to get ready. Drops the paper on the table.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT PAGE BLURB
dialogues.text: The article about O'HEARNE'S BOOK we previously saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney looks as though he's had the wind knocked out of h Solange approaches him carefully.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: You were a pallbearer at his funeral. (beat) Barney...? Off Barney's confusion --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney and Solange are in DR. MANDEBAUM'S office. Barney' long time physician.  WHITE 10-23-09 141.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Can I smoke in here?

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: hat do you think? Now be quiet and et Morty do his job.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MANDEBAUM
dialogues.text: I'm going to start by asking you a eries of questions. Just answer hem, there's no right or wrong. (beat) What month is it? an

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: You're joking.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MANDEBAUM
dialogues.text: here's a point to all this. 4

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: April.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MANDEBAUM
dialogues.text: What season is it?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Summer .

dialogues.speaker: DR. MANDEBAUM
dialogues.text: What city are we in?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Do you actually have a degree in medicine? (beat) Montreal.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MANDEBAUM
dialogues.text: What kind of car do you drive?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Morty, that's fucking embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MANDEBAUM
dialogues.text: Just answer it.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: A... you know, goddamn it... it's German... I can't even find the fucking thing. Why should I care what it's called? (to Solange) And why are you crying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRE-LAP: A phone dialing, then ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotch in hand, Barney paces while on the phone. Desperat and frantic without Miriam around.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Michael, hi, put your mother on the phone, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miriam is cleaning up clutter around Michael's apartment.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Nice to talk to you too, dad. (holding out phone) Mom. .

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Miriam, please come home already. I can't sleep without you beside me.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I know. I keep reaching over for you in bed and--

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I bought our cemetery plots today.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: (beat) What?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I can't handle being without you for even a few days, and that got me thinking and, well, I just needed that settled. That we'll be together forever.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Barney...  WHITE 10-23-09 113.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I've learned my lesson. Come back tonight. Please.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I wasn't punishing you. And you shouldn't have done that without talking to me first. That's a big thing.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: What does that mean? You're not sure?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Why is everything all or nothing with you? I say I need a little space, and you go out and buy real estate for our afterlife.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I just--

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Overreacted? Yes, you did. (beat) I'm sure what you bought is fine. What am I saying - if you bought it it's certainly the best plot in the whole city. But I'm still not coming home today. I'm enjoying my week with my son. Now I have to go, Blair is waiting for us at the restaurant. I love you--

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Blair?!

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Don't even start. He actually took YOUR advice and told them he had another offer. So they called him down for a final interview.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I can't believe you're there with Blair.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Barney, I'm not going to have this discussion with you. I love you but I really do have to go. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I love you.  WHITE 10-23-09 114. She hangs up. Barney looks around the big, empty house, going out of his mind, not knowing what to do with himsel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney's sitting at the bar chatting it up with Jill anda BLONDE (38) patron. He's already quite drunk.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: --And so he leaves his OWN wedding and chases after her onto the train.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: No way! You're crazy! Barney shrugs. Jill goes to serve another customer

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't remember me do you?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Should I?

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: I had a small part on your TV show a few years ago.

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: Really? I'm sorry, I don't remember.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: That's okay. I remembered you right away. (standing) I'm going to freshen up a bit, would you mind ordering me another? The look in her eye tells us exactly where this is going. Barney watches her walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blonde from the bar rolls off of Barney, naked, sweat and satisfied. Barney stares up at the ceiling. Too drunk and too horrified to process what he's just done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney, in a state of panic, bursts into Morty's office w is eating lunch at his desk

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
dialogues.text: I need a test. Now.  WHITE 10-23-09 115.

dialogues.speaker: DR. MANDEBAUM
dialogues.text: Test for what?

dialogues.speaker: BARNEY
